questions.question_text: Which of the following can occur when a scanning tool cannot authenticate to a server and has to rely on limited information obtained from service banners?

discussion.content:
The provided answer is corect 
"If the scanner can't authenticate on the end point, the scanner must rely on the limited information from anonymous network services probing such as the information retrieved from reading banners.

Banners might contain incorrect versions and outdated patch-level information, which results in false positives. However, if the scanner can authenticate, it can determine the full version of the operation system and patch-level information, and then suppress any false-positive vulnerabilities."

src: https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/SS42VS_7.4.0/com.ibm.qradar.doc/c_qvm_false_positive_vulns.html
Wow can you be more specific with your questions comptia. I'm over here thinking scanner meant vulnerabiltiy scanner smh

A is correct. Example for A - false positive
www.shodan.io lists entries based on Apache banner information
Distros stay on the initial upstream number and are backporting security patches
RHEL7 is based on Apache upstream v2.4.6 and still patched in 2020: httpd-2.4.6-93.el7.x86_64.rpm
shodan is just looking for httpd-2.4.6 and therefore listing all the known bugs
-google: how to hide apache version number

A. Today, there are a couple of options for manufacturers who want to put Wi-Fi capability in a coffee maker. One option is to use a Wi-Fi protected setup (WPS) button on the coffee maker and assume the user’s wireless router has a WPS button as well. This requires the user to press the button on the coffee pot and also press the button on the wireless router.
https://www.embedded-computing.com/embedded-computing-design/connecting-devices-to-the-internet-of-things-with-wi-fi

These are all terrible answers:
WPS - Not used anywhere that would have a systems engineer, but is probably the least awful answer, but still an awful answer.
WPA - uses TKIP, so you should use it.
EAP-FAST - unrelated.
802.1X - virtually no IoT devices support it.

comments.content:
Read these important facts from the question: integrate multiple legacy devices IoT into the company's wireless network securely
WPS: Typically, the devices will have a pushbutton. Activating this on the access point and the adapter simultaneously will associate the devices using a PIN, then associate the adapter with the access point using WPA2. 
To improve the functions of WEP, WiFi Protected Access or WPA was created in 2003.
WPS was designed by the Wi-Fi Alliance and introduced to the market in 2006, with the goal of allowing home users who don't want to fiddle with long wireless network passwords and security settings to quickly connect new wireless devices to their networks.

WPS was designed by the Wi-Fi Alliance and introduced to the market in 2006, with the goal of allowing home users who don't want to fiddle with long wireless network passwords and security settings to quickly connect new wireless devices to their networks.

YES A is ok
the key is when we use psk we do not need to log in each device especially when we we use internate of things device (IOT)
he “PSK” stands for “pre-shared key.” You set up a wireless passphrase on your router and then provide that same passphrase on each device you connect to your WI-Fi network. This essentially gives you a password that protects your Wi-FI network from unauthorized access. The router derives an encryption key from your passphrase, which it uses to encrypt your wireless network traffic to ensure people without the key can’t eavesdrop on it.

This can be a bit inconvenient, as you have to enter your passphrase on each new device you connect. Wi-FI Protected Setup (WPS), was created to solve this problem. When you connect to a router with WPS enabled, you’ll see a message saying you can use an easier way to connect rather than entering your Wi-Fi passphrase.

comments.content: This can be a bit inconvenient, as you have to enter your passphrase on each new device you connect. Wi-FI Protected Setup (WPS), was created to solve this problem. discussion.content: It 100% isn't WPS guys. WPS is used for EASE OF CONNECTIVITY, it did not even add security, in fact it was a feature that reduced your network's security. The right answer should be WPA as it can use TKIP to securely connect legacy devices. 802.1x does not support legacy and eapfast is unrelated

How "legacy" are we talking about? WPS was released in 2006, while WPA was released in 2003. Not all devices use WPS, so I'm not sure why the answer wouldn't be WPA. WPS is insecure. WPA is less secure than WPA2, but it's better than WPS. Where did the question mention using a quick, simple setup? That would indicate WPS to me.

questions.question_text: A systems administrator needs to integrate multiple IoT and small embedded devices into the company's wireless network securely. Which of the following should the administrator implement to ensure low-power and legacy devices can connect to the wireless network?

comments.content: Thanks man. I will go for 'D'. As I though 1-Full + 1-Differential + 1-Incremental + 1-Incremental.
I banged my desk when it said 'C' thinking 'How did I get this wrong again?!?!?!'. Glad for you guys to confirm I was correct :)

discussion.content: Shouldn't the answer be D? After all the Friday incremental backup has already finished by the time the RAID failed, so you need to restore Friday's incremental, as well as Sunday's full, Wednesday's differential and Thursday's incremental.

Answer is C=3
THE question is asking us to differentiate the three different types of disk failure and the minimum disk requirement for each of RAID. THESE ARE:

RAID LEVEL Zero 0
Following are the key points to remember for RAID level 0.
 Minimum 2 disks.
 Excellent performance ( as blocks are striped ).
 No redundancy ( no mirror, no parity ).
 Don’t use this for any critical system.
RAID LEVEL 1
Following are the key points to remember for RAID level 1.
 Minimum 2 disks.
 Good performance ( no striping. no parity ).
 Excellent redundancy ( as blocks are mirrored ).
RAID LEVEL 5

Following are the key points to remember for RAID level 5.
 Minimum 3 disks.
 Good performance ( as blocks are striped ).
 Good redundancy ( distributed parity ).
 Best cost effective option providing both performance and redundancy. Use this for DB that is heavily read oriented. Write operations will be sl
i am assuming that Monday is a new session for backups, So if it fails on Friday. You must recover backups form Friday, Saturday, and Sunday.

Looks like four to me... Failure occurs at 9pm all backups begin saving at 7pm. Now one can say that the backup on Friday 7pm didn't finish in-time to restore data from Friday. Which then it will give you three. I will go with provided answer... 1. Sunday Full backup, 2. Differential on Wednesday, 3. Incremental on Thursday, 4. Incremental on Friday.

Some questions are definitely wrong, so figuring out which ones are wrong is the problem.

comments.content: Backups take one hour to complete
But, they never mentioned that the failure was before the backup could complete or before the backup got initiated.

discussion.content: Answer is D
Answer is D you would need the two incremental backups from Friday and Thursday along with the differential and full backup.

comments.content: @SamEsther, how can it be 3? You would require 2 incrementals (2 Tapes) to cover thursday and friday, wednesday's differential will cover Mon+Tue+Wed, data (1 tape)and you would also require Sunday's Full (1 tape).

discussion.content:
The provided answer is Correct.
To complete, you would need Full Backup + Differential + Incremental

questions.question_text:
Management wants to ensure any sensitive data on company-provided cell phones is isolated in a single location that can be remotely wiped if the phone is lost.
Which of the following technologies BEST meets this need?

discussion.content: Key word: Isolated meaning contain in a specific areas in the mobile device

THE ANSWER IS A WHY HERE IS MY EXPLANATION
Containezration=Means isolation the company data from personal data
Encryption= Protecting Only the company data instead of encrypting the entire device
Geofencing: Organizations that require the mobile devices to be available only in a certain geographical location can make use of Geofencing to perform various actions like notifying the admin, corporate wipe or complete wipe when the device leave the geofence.
Terrible question

questions.question_text: A company is planning to utilize its legacy desktop systems by converting them into dummy terminals and moving all heavy applications and storage to a centralized server that hosts all of the company's required desktop applications. Which of the following describes the BEST deployment method to meet these requirements?

discussion.content:
With VDI, or a Virtual Desktop Infrastructure, you’re running applications in the cloud or in a data center, and you’re running as little of the application as possible on the local device. This virtualization of a user’s desktop is sometimes called VDE, or Virtual Desktop Environment.


https://www.professormesser.com/security-plus/sy0-501/security-in-the-cloud/
Keyword here is "terminals"

Virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) is defined as the hosting of desktop environments on a central server. It is a form of desktop virtualization, as the specific desktop images run within virtual machines (VMs) and are delivered to end clients over a network. Those endpoints may be PCs or other devices, like tablets or thin client terminals.
